perturbation.original_text: In the event that one Party is in breach of its obligations hereunder and fails to cure such breach within ten (10) Business Days following the other Party’s written notice thereof, then the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement;
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that one Party is in breach of its obligations hereunder and fails to cure such breach within two (2) Business Days following the other Party’s written notice thereof, then the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement;
perturbation.explanation: This change reduces the cure period for a breach of contract to two business days. This may be unreasonably short under PRC law, potentially conflicting with provisions requiring fair and reasonable opportunity to remedy a breach, especially considering the complexities of international business relationships.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially conflicts with PRC Contract Law Article 112, which implies a reasonable period for cure.

perturbation.original_text: Any dispute, conflict or claim arising out of or in connection with this Agreement or the performance hereof shall be resolved by the Parties through amicable negotiation, which negotiation shall commence immediately upon notice by one Party to the other of the nature of such dispute, conflict or claim. In the event that such dispute is not resolved within thirty (30) Business Days following such notice, either Party may upon the expiration of the such 30-day notice period submit such dispute to arbitration by the Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre in accordance with the arbitration rules of such centre then in effect.
perturbation.changed_text: Any dispute, conflict or claim arising out of or in connection with this Agreement or the performance hereof shall be resolved by the Parties through amicable negotiation, which negotiation shall commence immediately upon notice by one Party to the other of the nature of such dispute, conflict or claim. In the event that such dispute is not resolved within five (5) Business Days following such notice, either Party may upon the expiration of the such 5-day notice period submit such dispute to arbitration by the Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre in accordance with the arbitration rules of such centre then in effect.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the negotiation period to five business days is likely insufficient for resolving complex commercial disputes under PRC law, especially involving international parties. This could be seen as an unreasonable restriction on the parties' rights to seek resolution through negotiation, potentially conflicting with the principle of good faith negotiation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially conflicts with general principles of good faith negotiation and dispute resolution under PRC Contract Law.

perturbation.original_text: In the event that a Party’s performance of this Agreement or any covenants of the Parties is directly affected by an earthquake, typhoon, flood, fire, war, computer virus, design loophole in any software tool, hacker attack on the Internet, amendment to law or policy or any other event of force majeure which is not foreseeable or the result of which is not to be prevented or avoided, such Party shall immediately give the other Party a notice by fax of such event and within thirty days (30) thereafter provide a detailed report thereof as well as a certification document explaining the cause for the non-performance or delayed performance of this Agreement, which certification document shall be issued by the public notary of the region in which the event of force majeure occurred.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that a Party’s performance of this Agreement or any covenants of the Parties is directly affected by an earthquake, typhoon, flood, fire, war, computer virus, design loophole in any software tool, hacker attack on the Internet, amendment to law or policy or any other event of force majeure which is not foreseeable or the result of which is not to be prevented or avoided, such Party is not required to notify the other party of such event.
perturbation.explanation: Under PRC law, parties affected by force majeure events typically have a duty to notify the other party within a reasonable time and provide evidence substantiating the force majeure event. Eliminating the notification requirement entirely may violate this obligation, potentially leading to liability for breach of contract, even if the non-performance was genuinely caused by force majeure. In China, it is mandatory to provide a certificate from an authority.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially conflicts with PRC Contract Law Article 118, which requires timely notification of force majeure events.
